conclusion: Understanding the problem of finding maximum distance between two cars using v-t graphs.
Car A has a constant velocity after accelerating initially; Car B accelerates linearly.
Markings at t=10s and t=20s; horizontal line at 40 m/s; both cars have same velocity at t=20s.
Car A reaches 40 m/s before t=10s and stays constant; Car B reaches 40 m/s at t=20s.
Car A accelerates to 40 m/s before t=10s and maintains speed; Car B starts from rest and accelerates.
Cars are side by side at t=30s, meaning same position on the road.
Positions of cars at t=30s are equal.
Calculate area under velocity-time graph to find positions.
Equation for car A's velocity: va = 4t m/s for t ≤ 10s.
Position of car A for t ≤ 10s: xa = 2t² + c1; c1 = 0.
Position of car A for t > 10s: xa = 40t - 200 m.
Recalculate position of car A at t=10s: xa = 200 m.
Equation for car B's velocity: vb = 2t m/s.
Position of car B: xb = t² m.
Calculate positions at t=30s: xa = 1000 m, xb = 900 m.
